text.90:
Ayat ini menerangkan bahwa sebagaimana Allah telah meng-anugerahkan as-sab'ul-matsani kepada umat Nabi Muhammad, Dia juga telah menganugerahkan yang serupa itu kepada umat-umat sebelumnya dengan perantaraan nabi-nabi yang telah diutus kepada mereka. Seperti halnya sikap dan tindakan umat yang terdahulu terhadap kitab-kitab yang diturunkan kepada mereka, demikian pula sikap orang-orang musyrik di Mekah yang telah menamakan Al-Qur'an dengan nama yang bermacam-macam, seperti syair, sihir, dongeng-dongeng orang purbakala, buatan Muhammad, dan sebagainya.

Para mufasir berbeda pendapat tentang yang dimaksud dengan perkataan "al-muqtasimin" (orang yang membagi-bagi).

Pendapat pertama mengartikan al-muqtasimin dengan orang-orang kafir yang telah bersumpah bahwa Allah tidak akan membangkitkan orang yang mati. Perkataan ini sesuai dengan firman Allah swt:

Dan mereka bersumpah dengan (nama) Allah dengan sumpah yang sungguh-sungguh, "Allah tidak akan membangkitkan orang yang mati." Tidak demikian (pasti Allah akan membangkitkannya), sebagai suatu janji yang benar dari-Nya, tetapi kebanyakan manusia tidak mengetahui. (an-Nahl/16: 38)

Dan firman Allah swt:

Itukah orang-orang yang kamu telah bersumpah, bahwa mereka tidak akan mendapat rahmat Allah? (al-A'raf/7: 49)

Pendapat kedua mengartikan al-muqtasimin dengan "orang-orang yang membagi-bagi" kitab Allah, yaitu mengurangi, menukar, dan menambah isi kitab Allah yang telah diturunkan kepada para rasul-Nya. Dasar pendapat mereka ialah firman Allah swt:

¦Apakah kamu beriman kepada sebagian Kitab (Taurat) dan ingkar kepada sebagian (yang lain)?... (al-Baqarah/2: 85)

Dan firman Allah swt:

(Yaitu) di antara orang Yahudi, yang mengubah perkataan dari tempat-tempatnya¦ (an-Nisa'/4: 46)

Pendapat ketiga mengartikan al-muqtasimin dengan "orang-orang yang membagi-bagi". Maksudnya ialah mereka menamakan Al-Qur'an sesuai dengan nama yang mereka ingini, sehingga orang tidak mempercayai sebagai kitab yang diturunkan Allah. Alasan mereka ialah firman Allah swt:

Bahkan mereka mengatakan, "(Al-Qur'an itu buah) mimpi-mimpi yang kacau, atau hasil rekayasanya (Muhammad), atau bahkan dia hanya seorang penyair. (al-Anbiya/21: 5)

Firman Allah swt:

Lalu dia berkata, "(Al-Qur'an) ini hanyalah sihir yang dipelajari (dari orang-orang dahulu). (al-Muddatstsir/74: 24)

Setiap pendapat di atas mempunyai dalil-dalil yang kuat, tetapi yang lebih tepat dan sesuai dengan ayat-ayat ini ialah pendapat ketiga, apalagi jika dihubungkan dengan ayat-ayat selanjutnya, yaitu firman Allah yang artinya: "Yaitu orang-orang yang telah menjadikan Al-Qur'an itu terbagi-bagi".

Al-Maragi, menukil pendapat Ibnu Abbas, mengatakan bahwa orang-orang Yahudi dan Nasrani telah menjadikan pula Al-Qur'an itu terbagi-bagi, ada bagian yang mereka percayai, dan ada pula bagian yang mereka ingkari.

Hasan al-Basri berpendapat bahwa orang-orang musyrik Mekah telah membagi-bagi jalan yang akan dilalui manusia, kemudian mereka berdiri di jalan yang akan dilalui manusia dan menakut-nakuti orang-orang yang akan menempuh jalan yang telah dibentangkan oleh Nabi saw.

text.92: Ayat ini memerintahkan agar Nabi Muhammad memperingatkan orang-orang yang membagi-bagi Al-Qur'an dan tidak mempercayainya sebagai kitab suci bahwa Allah akan menurunkan azab kepada mereka sebagaimana Allah telah membinasakan umat-umat terdahulu karena perbuatan yang serupa dengan mereka.

text.94:
Ayat ini memerintahkan Nabi Muhammad saw agar menyiarkan agama Islam dengan terang-terangan, tidak lagi dengan sembunyi-sembunyi, menantang orang-orang musyrik, tidak mempedulikan mereka dan apa yang mereka katakan, dan tidak takut kepada mereka yang menghalanginya dalam menyiarkan agama Allah, karena Allah melindunginya dari gangguan mereka.

Sebagian ahli tafsir menafsirkan "Berpalinglah dari orang-orang musyrik" maksudnya adalah janganlah mempedulikan segala macam tindak-tanduk orang-orang musyrik yang telah mendustakan, memperolok-olok, dan menentang kamu. Janganlah tindakan mereka itu menghalangimu menyiarkan agama Allah, karena Allah memelihara kamu dari gangguan mereka.

text.96:
Ayat ini memberi jaminan kepada Nabi Muhammad bahwa Allah swt memeliharanya dari tindakan orang-orang musyrik Mekah yang memperolok-olok dan menyakitinya serta memelihara Al-Qur'an dari usaha-usaha orang-orang yang ingin mengotorinya.

Ath-thabari menyampaikan riwayat dari Sa'id bin Jubair bahwa orang-orang musyrik Mekah yang memperolok-olok Al-Qur'an dan Nabi Muhammad ialah al-Walid bin Mugirah, al-'As bin Wa'il, Al-'Adi bin Qais, Aswad bin Abdu Yaguts, dan Aswad bin Muththalib. Mereka semua terkenal dalam sejarah, dan sebab-sebab kematian mereka adalah akibat tindakan mereka sendiri.

Menurut suatu riwayat diterangkan bahwa suatu ketika Nabi saw berada di hadapan orang-orang kafir Mekah, mereka saling mengedipkan mata tanpa setahu Nabi Muhammad saw, dan berkata sesamanya dengan maksud mengejek Nabi, "Inikah orang yang mendakwakan dirinya nabi?" Pada waktu itu, Jibril a.s. menyertai Nabi, lalu Jibril menusuk punggung orang-orang yang memperolok-olokkan itu dengan jarinya, sehingga menimbulkan bekas, luka, dan borok yang busuk baunya. Tiada seorang pun yang mendekati mereka karena baunya itu. Maka turunlah ayat ini yang menegaskan bahwa Nabi saw dilindungi Allah swt dari gangguan orang-orang kafir.

Allah mengetahui bahwa Nabi saw merasa sedih karena olok-olokan dan tindakan orang-orang kafir. Untuk mengobati kesedihannya itu, Allah memerintahkan Nabi saw untuk bertasbih, mensucikan Allah dari segala sesuatu yang menyekutukan-Nya, salat, rukuk, sujud, banyak melakukan ibadah, berbuat baik, dan mengekang hawa nafsu. Hal ini berlaku pula bagi kaum Muslimin sampai akhir hayat mereka.

text.1:
This verse explains that the verses of the surah that will be explained belong to one of the surahs within the perfect and magnificent book, namely the Al-Qur'an, which Allah revealed to Prophet Muhammad saw, the last prophet. It is the most complete book among the books that Allah revealed to His messengers, confirming the previous books, and explaining the path to happiness and the path of error that previous peoples had taken. Thus, people can distinguish between the two paths, which one to take and which one to avoid and stay away from.

In the Al-Qur'an, there are also verses that explain about monotheism (tauhid), stories, good morals, knowledge, Allah's promises and His threats, and laws that become guidelines for humans in their lives and livelihoods in the world and in order to achieve salvation and happiness in the hereafter, as Allah swt says:

Alif Lam Ra. (This is) a Book whose verses are arranged precisely and then explained in detail from (One) Wise and Well-Acquainted. (Hud/11: 1)

And Allah swt says:

Alif Lam Mim Sad. (This is) a Book revealed to you (O Muhammad) - so let there not be in your breast distress therefrom - that you may warn thereby and as a reminder to the believers. (al-A'raf/7: 1-2)
text.2:
This verse is a warning from Allah SWT to the disbelievers, explaining to them that in the Hereafter, when they feel the severity of the torment of Hell, they will regret their actions and denial of the Almighty God during their lives in the world. If they had followed the call of the Messenger, carried out Allah's commands, abandoned His prohibitions, and worshipped Him with submission and obedience, they would certainly not be punished as they are on that day. If they had done the opposite, Allah would have admitted them into Paradise full of delights, as experienced by the Muslims at that time. However, at that time, all their regrets would be of no use. Allah SWT has decreed His decision, which cannot be changed, unless His power wills otherwise.

A hadith explains the moments of their regret:

From Abu Musa, may Allah be pleased with him, he said, "The Messenger of Allah SAW said, "When the inhabitants of Hell have gathered, and with them are those whom Allah wills from the people of the Qibla (believers), the disbelievers will say to the Muslims, "Were you not Muslims before?" The Muslims will say, "Yes." They will say, "Then your Islam which you adhered to before did not benefit you, so that you are gathered with us in this Hell?" The Muslims will say, "We committed sins, so we are punished for them." Then Allah SWT will hear their conversation, and He will command the Muslims who are in Hell to be brought out. When the disbelievers who remain see that, they will say, "Oh, if only we had been Muslims, then we would have been brought out of Hell, just as they were brought out." Abu Musa said, "Then the Messenger of Allah SAW said, "I seek refuge in Allah from the accursed Satan." And then he recited this verse." (Narrated by ath-Thabrani)

Allah SWT's statement that is similar to this verse is:

"If you could but see when they will be made to stand before the Fire and will say, "Oh, would that we could be returned [to life on earth] and not deny the signs of our Lord and be among the believers!" (al-An'am/6: 27)

As mentioned in al-Maragi, Az-Zajjaj said, "Indeed, the disbelievers, when they see the state of the torment of Hell and see the state of the Muslims in Paradise, they will wish that they had been Muslims when they were in the world."

Thus, Allah depicts the character of humans who are ungrateful to Allah. They only remember Allah when danger and torment befall them, but when the danger and torment have disappeared, they return to being ungrateful to Allah, their helper and creator. The same thing happens to the disbelievers who wish to return to life in the world to worship, and they promise that if their wishes are granted, they will believe sincerely and will not be ungrateful again as before. If humans truly wanted to believe, Allah SWT's guidance conveyed by His prophets and messengers would have been sufficient, but most humans are influenced by the pleasures of worldly life, which are temporary. They enslave themselves more to the accursed Satan than to Allah, their Creator. They have been given enough opportunities to repent while in the world, but they ignore those opportunities. After they are in the Hereafter, that opportunity will not be given again. For them, Allah's decree applies, which will punish everyone who disbelieves in Him.

This verse is a stern warning to the polytheists of Arabia in particular, and to the disbelievers in general, especially those who hinder the spread of Allah's religion on earth. For the Prophet SAW and his companions, this verse is good news. At the time of the revelation of this verse, the disbelievers were strongly hindering the implementation of the Islamic da'wah that the Prophet SAW and his companions were carrying out. In fact, the polytheists of Mecca had reached the point of committing acts of persecution accompanied by severe threats against the followers of the Prophet Muhammad, so that the Prophet and his companions almost despaired and worried, if the task entrusted by Allah could not be carried out properly. The revelation of this verse gave rise to a sense of optimism. Their steadfastness and patience increased in spreading Allah's religion because they truly believed that Islam would definitely develop and the most genuine victory is the victory that will be obtained in the Hereafter.

From this verse and the hadith above, it can be understood that the reward or punishment that will be received by those who believe and those who disbelieve is commensurate and in accordance with the actions they have done while in the world.
text.3:
In the verse above, Allah SWT has described to the disbelievers their state in the Hereafter and when they endure a painful torment. However, that description leaves no impression whatsoever on their hearts; they even consider Allah's warning to be completely meaningless. In this verse, Allah commands the Messenger of Allah SAW, if they remain in disbelief even after receiving warnings and lessons, to leave them in their negligence and heedlessness as they have been, enjoying and savoring all the pleasures and delights of life in this world and indulging their desires. The Messenger is also commanded to let them eat food and do as they please until the appointed time, to dream and imagine that they will obtain countless riches, obtain what they desire, such as many descendants, beautiful palaces, and impose their will on enemies and whomever they wish.

The warning conveyed by Allah is a severe threat to the disbelievers, that their actions and deeds are contrary to the teachings of Allah's religion, contrary to the character and personality of a Muslim.

The destruction of Muslim character and personality is depicted in the words of the Prophet SAW:

From Amr bin Syuaib from the Prophet SAW, he said, "The goodness of the first generation of this ummah is with asceticism (zuhud) and certainty (keyakinan). While the later ummah will be corrupted by stinginess and their aspirations." (Narrated by Ahmad, ath-Thabrani and al-Baihaqi)

Ali bin Abi Thalib said, "Indeed, what I fear for you are two things, namely, lengthy aspirations and indulging in desires. For indeed, lengthy aspirations cause one to forget the Hereafter, while indulging in desires prevents the implementation of truth."

The destruction of Muslim character and personality is depicted in the words of the Prophet SAW:

From Amr bin Syuaib from the Prophet SAW, he said, "The goodness of the first generation of this ummah is with asceticism (zuhud) and certainty (yaqin). While the later ummah will be corrupted by stinginess and their aspirations." (Narrated by Ahmad, ath-Thabrani, and al-Baihaqi)

Ali bin Abi Talib said, "Indeed, what I fear for you are two things: lengthy aspirations and indulging in desires. For indeed, lengthy aspirations make one forget the Hereafter, while indulging in desires prevents the implementation of truth."
text.5:
This verse explains that there is no city that Allah destroys except that Allah has determined the time of its destruction in Lauh Mahfudh. Nothing is forgotten to be written by Him, nothing is late, and nothing happens before the appointed time.

From this verse, it can be understood that Allah SWT will not punish a people before there is a reason to inflict punishment. The reason meant is that a messenger has been sent to that people to convey the religion of Allah, but they reject the messenger or deny his teachings.

This verse is a warning to the polytheists of Mecca who always hinder the Messenger of Allah and his companions from conveying his message. This warning also applies to those who come later who commit actions similar to the various actions of the polytheists of Mecca. Allah's decree and warning are certain to apply.
text.6:
This verse explains the words and mockery of the Meccan disbelievers towards the Prophet Muhammad saw when the verses of the Al-Qur'an were conveyed to them. They said, "O Muhammad, you who claim to be a prophet and messenger of Allah and to whom the Al-Qur'an has been revealed. In reality, your words and preaching show that you are truly insane or have signs of insanity, because the Al-Qur'an has no meaning or significance whatsoever, contradicting our opinions, and violating the beliefs inherited from our ancestors. Is it possible for us to accept something that is not in accordance with our minds and is also disliked by our wise men and scholars?"

From the words of the disbelievers, their true attitude towards the Al-Qur'an and the Prophet Muhammad saw is clearly visible. They refuted the Al-Qur'an without thinking about and contemplating the proofs and arguments mentioned in it, which explain the signs of Allah's power and greatness that exist within themselves, in the livestock they raise, in the plants they cultivate to meet their needs, in the earth where they reside, in the universe, and so on. They denied and rejected all of that without reflecting and thinking beforehand.

Their attitude arose from the error of their hearts, stubbornness, and fanaticism towards their ancestors, which had been deeply ingrained in them, as Allah swt says:

Every time a new reminder comes to them from their Lord, they listen to it playfully. Their hearts are heedless. And those who do wrong conceal their private conversations, saying, "Is this [man] anything but a human being like yourselves? So would you approach magic while you are aware?" (al-Anbiya'/21: 2-3)

Because of their unwillingness to pay attention and their deep fanaticism, they denied the verses of the Al-Qur'an, as Allah swt says:

And no sign comes to them from the signs of their Lord but that they turn away from it. (al-An'am/6: 4)

Their attitude created arrogance and pride within them, as Allah swt says:

And those who do not expect the meeting with Us say, "Why are not the angels sent down to us, or [why] do we [not] see our Lord?" They have certainly thought too highly of themselves and transgressed with great transgression. (al-Furqan/25: 21)
text.7:
Furthermore, the disbelievers said, "If you, O Muhammad, truly believe in the truth of what you convey and believe that you are indeed a prophet and messenger of Allah, sent to us, then you should be able to ask Him to send an angel from the sky with you, who can strengthen and prove your prophethood and messengership to us."

From their request, their way of thinking about prophethood and messengership is illustrated. According to them, if a prophet or messenger is sent, there must be an angel accompanying him, so that the angel can strengthen his prophethood and messengership, make it easier for people to accept his message, or the prophet should simply be an angel. According to their way of thinking, only spiritual beings bring the verses of Allah, while humans are physical beings (visible). Humans, even if they have high power, still cannot be prophets and messengers, because they still associate with humans, are in their midst, and still have physical needs, such as eating, drinking, dressing, wanting power, wanting to accumulate wealth, being attracted to worldly life, and so on. Therefore, it is impossible for a human to become a prophet and messenger, unless the appointment of prophethood and messengership is strengthened or confirmed by the presence of an angel as a companion.

The belief of the polytheists of Mecca is like the belief of Pharaoh and his followers about messengers and prophets. According to them, all messengers sent by Allah should be appointed with a ceremony full of majesty and greatness, like the appointment of their kings, wearing bracelets and necklaces made of gold and ceremonial clothes, or the messenger should come accompanied by angels, as explained in the word of Allah SWT:

"Then why are bracelets of gold not put upon him (Moses), or why do angels not come with him in procession?" Thus he (Pharaoh) influenced his people, and they obeyed him. Indeed, they were a people defiantly disobedient [to Allah]. (az-Zukhruf/43: 53-54)
text.8:
Allah answers the mockery and ridicule of the Meccan polytheists with this verse, stating that He will not send down angels because there is no wisdom or benefit in it. This means that even if Allah SWT sent down angels from the sky and appointed them as messengers conveying His religion, it would be of no use and would not be able to convince or straighten the beliefs of the polytheists. As is known, angels are unseen and subtle beings, so human eyes would not be able to see them. If Allah SWT willed and made the angels appear in human form, so that human eyes could see them, and then Allah sent them as prophets and messengers to them, the angels would eat and drink like them, walk and associate with them. Then, the thought would arise in their minds that the angel assigned as a messenger was also a human like them, not an angel. In other words, doubt would continue to exist within them. This is explained in the word of Allah SWT:

"And if We had made him an angel, We would have certainly made him a man, and We would have certainly confused them about what they are already confused about." (al-An'am/6: 9)

From their attitude and manner as stated in the word of Allah above, it is proven that their hearts are actually closed to receiving the truth. No matter what evidence is presented to them, they will still not believe. Allah SWT says:

"And even if We had sent down to them angels and the dead had spoken to them and We had gathered together all things before them, they would not believe unless Allah willed. But most of them are ignorant (of the truth)." (al-An'am/6: 111)

Because of their attitude, Allah gives them a stern warning that if an angel is sent down, it is a sign that they will be struck by a great disaster and destroyed, so that their history will end. This provision is in accordance with the *sunatullah* that has applied to previous peoples who have mocked the messengers of Allah who were sent to them. Before the punishment was inflicted, angels were sent to them, as happened to the people of Lut, as in the word of Allah SWT:

"[The angels] said, "O Lot, indeed, we are messengers of your Lord; they will never reach you. So set out with your family during a portion of the night and let not any among you look back - except your wife. Indeed, she will be struck by that which strikes them. Indeed, their appointment is [for] the morning. Is not the morning near?" (Hud/11: 81)

Mujahid, in the interpretation of this verse, says that Allah sends down angels only as messengers of Allah, a sign of the coming of punishment, or bringers of Allah's punishment.
text.9:
This verse is a stern warning for those who neglect the Qur'an and do not believe that the Qur'an was revealed by Allah to His Messenger Muhammad. It is as if Allah is saying to them, "You, O disbelievers, are actually misguided people who mock the Prophet and Messenger whom We have sent to convey the religion of Islam to you. Indeed, your attitude will not affect the purity and sanctity of the Qur'an in the slightest, because We are the ones who revealed it. You accuse Muhammad of being mad, but We affirm that We Ourselves are guarding the Qur'an from all attempts to defile it and attempts to add to, subtract from, or change its verses. We will protect it from all forms of human interference. The time will come when people will memorize, read, study, and explore its contents, so that they may obtain from the Qur'an guidance and wisdom, moral guidance and good character, knowledge and guidelines for thinking for experts and intellectuals, as well as guidance to the path of life in this world and the Hereafter."

Allah SWT's guarantee regarding the preservation of the Qur'an is further affirmed in His saying:

"They want to extinguish the light of Allah with their mouths, but Allah will perfect His light, although the disbelievers dislike it." (as-shaff/61: 8)

Regarding Allah's guarantee of the sanctity and purity of the Qur'an and the affirmation that Allah Himself is preserving it, it is proven by observing and studying the history of the revelation of the Qur'an, the methods used by the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) when propagating, preserving, and correcting the recitation of the Companions, prohibiting writing other than the verses of the Qur'an, and so on. Then, this effort to preserve the Qur'an was continued by the Companions, the Tabi'in (the generation after the Companions), and by every generation of Muslims who came after them, until now.

To know and prove that the Qur'an that has reached us today is preserved in its purity, it is explained in the history of the Qur'an, both in the time of the Messenger of Allah and in the time of the Companions, and the efforts of Muslims to preserve it at this time. On the other hand, the authenticity of the Qur'an can be traced from the history of its writing and recitation.

First:

The Qur'an was revealed gradually to the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) over a period of approximately 23 years. Every time a verse was revealed, the Prophet instructed his Companions to memorize it and write it down on stones, animal skins, and palm leaves. The Prophet had several Companions who were tasked with writing down the revelation and accompanying him when a verse was revealed. Among the writers of the revelation were Zaid bin Thabit, Ali bin Abi Talib, Uthman bin Affan, Ubay bin Ka'ab, and others.

Every time a verse was revealed, the Prophet explained to the writers of the revelation in which part of the verses that had been revealed earlier or in which surah the verse should be placed and written. He forbade the Companions from writing anything other than the Qur'an, whether it was his explanation that became the tafsir (interpretation) of the verse or information written by the Companions themselves. A hadith of the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) as narrated by Abu Sa'id al-Khudri:

"Do not write anything from me except the Qur'an. Whoever has written anything other than the Qur'an, let him erase it." (Narrated by Muslim)

The general prohibition was to maintain the purity of the writing of the Qur'an so that it would not be mixed with other writings besides the Qur'an, whether sourced from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) or the Companions. However, there were some Companions who were indeed literate, writing down the sayings of the Messenger as interpretations of the Qur'an and their notes, such as 'Abdullah bin 'Umar, 'Abdullah bin Mas'ud, Ali bin Abi Talib, Ibn Abbas, and others.

In addition to being written by the writers of the revelation and some of the Companions, the Qur'an was also memorized by the Companions and required to be recited in prayer.

Given the importance of the role of writing and reading in maintaining the authenticity or purity of the Qur'an, the Prophet greatly appreciated people who were literate and encouraged his Companions to learn it. After the Battle of Badr, the Prophet used the prisoners of war from Badr who were literate to redeem themselves by teaching 10 Muslim children to read and write. With this decision of the Messenger, the more people who could read and write, the more people who could record and memorize the Qur'an.

Thus, there are three factors that helped preserve the writing and recitation of the Qur'an:

1. The writing or manuscripts written by the writers of the revelation.

2. The memorization of the Companions who were very enthusiastic about memorizing it.

3. Personal writings or manuscripts written by the Companions who were already literate, such as 'Abdullah bin 'Umar, 'Abdullah bin Mas'ud, Ali bin Abi Talib, and others.

In addition to the three factors above, the Angel Jibril (Gabriel) always checked the Prophet's recitation of the Qur'an every year. During the check, the Messenger was instructed to repeat the recitation of the Qur'an that had been revealed. Even before his death, the Angel Jibril checked it twice.

The Prophet himself often checked the recitation of his Companions. They were instructed to recite the Qur'an in his presence, and he corrected their recitation.

The Prophet died after the Qur'an had been completely revealed and had been memorized by many people according to the order of the Qur'an that we read today, in accordance with the guidance he gave when reciting the Qur'an, both in and out of prayer. With the practical method of practice above, the Qur'an could be preserved in its purity and spread easily in society.

After the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) died, the Companions agreed to choose Abu Bakr as caliph. At the beginning of his reign, many of the Muslims who had not yet strengthened their faith became apostates, and some of them claimed to be prophets. Therefore, Abu Bakr fought them. In this war, 70 memorizers of the Qur'an were killed, and before that, several others had also been killed. At the suggestion of Umar bin Khaththab and accepted by Abu Bakr, Zaid bin Thabit was assigned to rewrite the Qur'an, the manuscript of which had been written in the time of the Prophet and supported by the memorization of the Companions who were still alive. After completing the writing on sheets, tied with thread, arranged according to the order that had been determined by the Messenger of Allah, the mushaf (codex) was then handed over to Abu Bakr. After Abu Bakr died, this mushaf was handed over to his successor, Umar bin al-Khaththab. After Umar died, this mushaf was kept in the house of Hafsah, the daughter of Umar and the wife of the Messenger of Allah, until the time of the compilation of the Qur'an in the time of Caliph Uthman bin Affan.

During the reign of Caliph Uthman bin Affan, the territory of the Islamic government had reached Armenia and Azerbaijan in the east and Tripoli in the west. Thus, the Companions at that time had been scattered in Egypt, Syria, Iraq, Persia, and Africa. Wherever they went and wherever they lived, the Qur'an al-Karim remained their imam (leader), and many of them memorized the Qur'an. They had copies of the Qur'an, but the copies they had were not the same in the arrangement of the surahs because they were recorded according to their understanding or were still mixed with the explanations of the Messenger as its tafsir.

This caused disputes about the recitation of the Qur'an among them. The origin of this difference in recitation was because the Messenger of Allah himself gave leniency to the Arab tribes who were in his time to recite and pronounce the Qur'an according to their respective dialects. This leniency was given by the Prophet so that they could easily pronounce and memorize the Qur'an.

But then there was concern that the dispute about the recitation of the Qur'an, if left alone, would bring unwanted disputes and divisions among the Muslims.

The first person to show concern about this was a Companion named Huzaifah bin Yaman. He participated in the war to conquer Armenia and Azerbaijan. During the journey, he had heard Muslims arguing about the recitation of several verses of the Qur'an and had heard a Muslim say to his friend, "My recitation is better than your recitation."

When this was conveyed to Caliph Uthman bin Affan, he immediately agreed to the writing of the Qur'an, so a team was immediately formed consisting of the writers of the revelation, such as Zaid bin Thabit who became the head of the team, 'Abdullah bin Zubair, Sa'id bin 'As and 'Abdurrahman bin Haris bin Hisyam, and others.

The mushaf containing sheets written with the Qur'an, which had been compiled by Caliph Abu Bakr, and stored in the house of Hafsah, was requested back by Uthman. Because this team was tasked with copying the writing of the Qur'an in the mushaf and standardizing its recitation and writing. The results of this team's work will become the reference and reference for the recitation of the Qur'an for Muslims throughout the world.

In carrying out its duties, this team imposed the following conditions:

1. Only what is believed to be truly the Qur'an is written, referring to the writing and memorization of the Companions.

2. Only verses that are believed to have never been *naskh* (abrogated) are written.

3. If there is a word that has several different readings, then it is written in the dialect of Quraysh because the majority of the Qur'an is written in that dialect.

4. If there are two different readings but can be accommodated in one writing, it is written in one writing such as *malik* and *malik*.

The mushaf that has been standardized in its recitation is known as *al-Mushaf al-Imam* or *al-Mushaf al-'Uthmani*. This mushaf was duplicated into five mushafs, each sent to Mecca, Syria, Basra, Kufa, and one left in Medina.

Thus, the Qur'an was compiled in the time of the Companions. All mushafs that are published later must be adjusted to *al-Mushaf al-Imam*. Then the effort to maintain the purity of the Qur'an was continued by Muslims throughout the world, until the current generation.

To maintain the purity of the Qur'an in Indonesia, various efforts are made, including:

1. Forming the "Lajnah Pentashihan Mushaf Al-Qur'an" (Committee for the Authentication of Qur'anic Manuscripts) which is tasked with, among other things, examining all mushafs that will be printed before being distributed to the public. The team is under the supervision of the Minister of Religious Affairs.

2. The government has a copy of the Qur'an that is the standard in the publication of the Qur'an in Indonesia, which has been adjusted to the *Mushaf al-Imam*.

3. Holding the Musabaqah Tilawatil Qur'an (Qur'anic Recitation Competition) every year which is handled and managed by the state.

4. Other efforts made by the Muslim community, such as forming educational institutions, studies, and tahfiz (memorization) of the Qur'an.

Second:

After 'Uthman bin 'Affan died, *al-Mushaf al-Imam* was still considered the sole guide by Muslims in the recitation of the Qur'an. Nevertheless, there were also some differences in the recitation. The reasons for the emergence of these differences can be summarized in two things:

First: The writing of the Qur'an itself was not yet perfect.

Second: The differences in the dialects of the Arabs.

The writing of the Qur'an can cause differences because *al-Mushaf al-Imam* was written by the Companions whose writing cannot be said to be perfect because it had not received punctuation marks and dots. As explained by Ibn Khaldun in his book "Muqaddimah Ibn Khaldun," he said, "Pay attention to the consequences that occur because of the writing of the mushaf written by the Companions themselves with their hands. The writing is not perfect, so sometimes there are some errors in understanding the reading from the writing because it is without dots and lines."

As for the differences in the dialects of the Arabs that have been tolerated by the Messenger of Allah, they gave rise to various kinds of *qira'at* (readings), so that in the year 200 Hijriah, there emerged countless experts in *qira'at*.

Among the famous dialects of the Arabic language are the *lahjah* (dialect) of Quraysh, Hudzail, Tamim, Asad, Rabiah, Hawazin, and Sa'ad. At that time, famous experts in *qira'at* emerged, and the most famous were seven people, namely: 'Abdullah bin Amir, Abu Ma'bad 'Abdullah bin Kathir, Abu Bakar Asim bin Abi an-Najud, Abu Amr bin A'la, Nafi' bin Abi Nu'aim, Abul Hasan 'Ali bin Hamzah al-Kisa'i, Abu Jarah bin Habib Ibnu Zayyat/Hamzah. These *qira'at* were popularized by people under the name "Qiraat Sab'ah" (the seven readings).

As explained above, the Qur'an was initially written without dots and lines, but this did not affect the recitation of the Qur'an because the Companions and the Tabi'in, in addition to memorizing the Qur'an, were also fluent in the Arabic language. Therefore, they could recite it well and accurately. But after the religion of Islam spread and many non-Arabs embraced the religion of Islam, it was difficult for them to recite the Qur'an without dots and lines. It was greatly feared that this would cause errors in the recitation of the Qur'an.

So Abul Aswad Ad-Duali took the initiative to give punctuation marks in the Qur'an with ink of a different color. A dot above for *fathah*, a dot below for *kasrah*, a dot on the upper left for *dhamah*, and two dots for *tanwin*. This happened during the time of Ali bin Abi Talib.

Then, during the reign of Caliph Abdul Malik bin Marwan, Nasr bin Asim and Yahya bin Ya'mar added signs for the letters that had dots with the same ink as the writing of the Qur'an to distinguish between the meaning of the dot of Abul Aswad Ad-Duali and this new dot. The dot of Abul Aswad was for punctuation and the dot of Nasr bin Asim was the dot of the letter. This method of writing remained in effect during the Umayyad dynasty, and at the beginning of the Abbasid kingdom, and was even used in Spain until the middle of the fourth century Hijriah. Then it turned out that this method of giving signs still caused difficulties for the readers of the Qur'an because there were too many dots, and the dots gradually became almost the same color.

So al-Khalil took the initiative to make new signs, namely a small *wau* above for *dhammah*, a small letter *alif* for the sign of *fathah*, a small letter *ya* for the sign of *kasrah*, the head of the letter *sin* for the sign of *syiddah*, the head of *ha* for *sukun* and the head of *'ain* for *hamzah*.

Then these signs were simplified by being cut and added to so that they became the forms that exist today.

Thus, the efforts of the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and the Muslims to preserve and protect the Qur'an from all kinds of human interference, so that the Qur'an that is in the hands of Muslims today is exactly the same as the Qur'an that was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him). This is proof of Allah's guarantee that He will continue to preserve the Qur'an forever.
text.10:
With this verse, Allah swt comforts the heart of Prophet Muhammad saw who was saddened and suffering due to the mockery, insults, and oppression of the polytheists of Mecca. He felt sad about the ignorance of his people who refused to understand the Qur'an, even accusing him of being insane. Allah swt explains that what Prophet Muhammad was experiencing had also been experienced by the previous messengers who were sent to earlier peoples. Almost all of those peoples mocked the messengers, and some even made evil plans to kill them. They denied the call of the messengers and continued to practice the customs and beliefs inherited from their ancestors. Almost all the messengers were sent to their people alone, without friends or helpers to assist them, except for the helpers and supporters they gained after much preaching. Generally, the messengers were poor people, without dignitaries or rulers to support them, and without sufficient wealth to finance their da'wah, but all the messengers were trustworthy, steadfast, and patient in carrying out the tasks entrusted to them.

With this verse, it is as if Allah swt affirms to Prophet Muhammad not to despair because of the attitudes and actions of the disbelievers, because all the messengers experienced such trials and challenges. The attitude of the disbelievers is because their morals have been corrupted, and their desires have overcome all the truth that might enter their hearts. Therefore, they cannot accept the truth of the verses of the Qur'an that are conveyed to them.

text.12:
This verse explains the response of the disbelievers to the Qur'an. They mock it and do not accept it. This is because the attitude of denial and mockery has flourished in their hearts, so that there is no longer any willingness in them to accept the truth. In their hearts, there is no longer a lamp that emits light that can guide and illuminate the path to the truth. Their condition is the same as the condition of the previous peoples who received the Book of Allah conveyed by the messengers, but nothing remained in their hearts.

Therefore, for the people to whom messengers have been sent, but they deny the call of the messenger, *sunnatullah* applies, namely that Allah will destroy everyone who disobeys the messenger and the message he conveys, and help and give victory to those who accept his call.

At some point in the future, the disbelievers will know the truth of the news and warnings of the Qur'an, as affirmed in the word of Allah swt:

"And you will surely know its news after a time." (Shad/38: 88)

The truth of the news of the Qur'an referred to in the verse above, some of which are realized in the world, such as the truth of Allah's promise to the believers that they will win in the war against the polytheists, and some of which are realized in the Hereafter, such as the truth of Allah's promise about the recompense and reckoning that will be carried out against humans on the Last Day.

text.14:
This verse explains that the polytheists of Mecca were people who were very ungrateful and unwilling to accept the truth. Their condition is described by Allah in this verse. Even if Allah were to open the gates of heaven for them and provide ladders for them to ascend to heaven, they still would not believe.

Even if they saw angels in the sky or a miracle that was a sign of Allah's power and greatness, they would not acknowledge it. Instead, they would say, "Our eyes have been blinded so that we cannot clearly see any sign before us. What we see is nothing but an illusion, the result of Muhammad's magic that has bewitched us, so that we no longer see the reality of the truth." This verse is in line with the word of Allah swt:

And even if We had sent down to you (O Muhammad) a written scripture on a page and they could touch it with their hands, the disbelievers would surely say, "This is nothing but obvious magic." (al-An'am/6: 7)
text.15:
This verse explains that the polytheists of Mecca were people who were very ungrateful and unwilling to accept the truth. Their condition is described by Allah in this verse. Even if Allah opened the gates of heaven for them and provided ladders to ascend to it, they would still ascend.

Even if they saw angels in the sky or a miracle that was a sign of Allah's power and greatness, they would not acknowledge it. Instead, they would say, "Our eyes have been blinded so that we cannot see clearly any sign before us. What we see is nothing but an illusion, the result of Muhammad's magic that has bewitched us, so that we no longer see the essence of truth." This verse is in line with Allah SWT's saying:

"And even if We had sent down to you, [O Muhammad], a written scripture on a page and they could touch it with their hands, the disbelievers would say, "This is not but obvious magic." (al-An'am/6: 7)
text.16:
This verse explains that Allah swt created various celestial objects in the form of countless planets, the moon, and stars, all of which adorn the sky, thus captivating the hearts of those who behold them. All of this becomes material for reflection for those who are willing to think, especially in seeking their benefits for humans and humanity, as Allah swt says in another verse:

Mahasuci Allah who has placed in the sky constellations and has placed therein a sun and a moon emitting light. And it is He who has made the night and the day in succession for whoever desires to remember or desires gratitude. (al-Furqan/25: 61-62)

In another verse, Allah swt also explains:

And We have certainly beautified the nearest heaven with stars. (al-Mulk/67: 5)

The stars that Allah created are some that do not shine and some that do shine, twinkling at night, as Allah swt says:

And He completed them as seven heavens within two days and inspired in each heaven its command. And We adorned the nearest heaven with lamps and as protection. That is the determination of (Allah) the Exalted in Might, the Knowing. (Fussilat/41: 12)

And the word of Allah swt:

And We have certainly beautified the nearest heaven with stars and have made them missiles for the devils and have prepared for them the punishment of the Blaze. (al-Mulk/67: 5)

These celestial bodies are guides for travelers walking in the middle of the desert at night, ships sailing in the middle of the ocean, as well as airplanes and spacecraft flying to their destinations. The movement of the sun, moon, and stars can also be used as a basis for knowing the number of days, the number of years, and the calculation of time, as Allah swt says:

It is He who made the sun a shining light and the moon a derived light and determined for it phases - that you may know the number of years and account [of time]. Allah has not created this except in truth. He details the signs for a people who know. (Yunus/10: 5)

The atmosphere of the night when the sky is clear and cloudless, the stars are scattered in the vast expanse of space and their light that appears and disappears, and the light of the full moon brings peace to the hearts of those who have believed in Allah. All of this strengthens their faith, so that without realizing it, their mouths utter words that glorify Allah.
text.17:
This verse explains that Allah swt protects the heavens and its contents from the accursed devils. In another verse, Allah swt says:

And We have guarded it against every rebellious devil. (as-shaffat/37: 7)

Meanwhile, there are devils who disregard Allah's prohibitions. They seek news that they might hear from the angels, so such devils are hunted by fiery darts that burn them, causing them to flee and not have time to hear the conversations of the angels. This is explained by the word of Allah swt:

They cannot listen to the Highest Assembly (of angels) and are pelted from every side. (as-shaffat/37: 8)

And the word of Allah swt:

And we (the jinn) sought to reach the heaven, but found it filled with stern guards and flaming fires. And we used to sit there in places to listen, but whoever listens now will find a flame lying in wait for him. (al-Jinn/72: 8-9)

As mentioned above, there are several verses that explain the various attempts of devils to listen to the conversations of the angels in the heavens, but before they have a chance to hear it, they are chased and burned by hot fiery darts. This is a matter of the unseen (ghaib) because it is difficult to know and cannot be seen by human eyes, nor can its true nature be known, nor are there any proofs that can be used as a basis for determining the true meaning of the verse. Because what explains this is the Al-Qur'an and human thought has not reached it, then it is obligatory for Muslims to believe in it, and to believe that the heavens and the earth and the universe are the property of Allah the Creator. Allah swt guards and manages all of His possessions. How He manages and guards it, human knowledge about it is very little. Likewise, how the devil spies on the conversations of the angels and what the form of the fiery darts that hunt the devil is. Only Allah knows.
text.18:
This verse explains that Allah SWT protects the heavens and its contents from the accursed devils. In another verse, Allah SWT says:

"And We have guarded it against every rebellious devil." (as-Saffat/37: 7)

Meanwhile, there are devils who disregard Allah's prohibitions. They seek news that they might hear from the angels, so such devils are hunted by fiery flames that burn them, causing them to flee and not have time to hear the conversations of the angels. This is explained by the word of Allah SWT:

"They cannot listen to the Highest Assembly (of angels) and are pelted from every side." (as-Saffat/37: 8)

And the word of Allah SWT:

"And we (the jinn) sought to reach the heaven, but found it filled with stern guards and flaming fires. And we used to sit there in places to listen, but whoever listens now will find a flame lying in wait for him." (al-Jinn/72: 8-9)

As mentioned above, there are several verses that explain the various attempts of devils to listen to the conversations of the angels in the heavens, but before they have a chance to hear it, they are chased and burned by hot flames. This is a matter of the unseen (ghaib) because it is difficult to know and cannot be seen by human eyes, nor can its true nature be known, nor are there any proofs that can be used as a basis for determining the true meaning of the verse. Because what explains this is the Al-Qur'an and human thought has not reached it, then it is obligatory for Muslims to believe in it, and to believe that the heavens and the earth and the universe are the property of Allah the Creator. Allah SWT guards and regulates all of His possessions. How He regulates and guards them, human knowledge about it is very little. Likewise, how the devil spies on the conversations of the angels and what the shape of the flames that hunt the devil are. Only Allah knows.
text.19:
After Allah SWT explained the signs of His greatness and power in the heavens, in this verse, Allah explains the signs of His power that can be seen, known, felt, and thought about by humans. Among them, Allah created the earth as if it were spread out, making it easy for humans to inhabit, allowing them to cultivate it, and making it easier for them to travel to all corners of the world in search of lawful sustenance and enjoyment.

Allah created deep ravines on the earth and small rivers that flow and then unite into large rivers leading to the vast ocean. He also created mountains that tower into the sky, adorned with a variety of green plants and vegetation, which please the hearts of those who look at them, as Allah says:

"And it is He who spread out the earth and placed therein firmly set mountains and rivers; and from all fruits He made therein pairs. He covers the night with the day. Indeed in that are signs for a people who give thought." (ar-Ra'd/13: 3)

Verse 19 of Surah al-Hijr implies how geological processes take place over tens, hundreds, or even millions of years. According to scientists, the geological process is essentially a never-ending cycle. At the bottom of the ocean, such as in the Pacific Ocean, there is a process of spreading magmatic materials that come out of the mid-ocean ridge continuously and form oceanic plates [see explanation of an-Naml/27: 88 and at-Thur/52: 6]. This plate continues to move and collide with other plates.

Meanwhile, there is also an erosion process that starts from high places, and then the eroded material is spread and deposited in lower places. This sediment then experiences pressure due to the movement of the plates, causing the layers of rock resulting from erosion to bend and rise, forming mountains. See also an-Nahl/16: 15 which is related to this verse.

How great is Allah who created all of that, the benefits and blessings of which can be felt by humans, but most of them deny their Creator.

Allah has created a variety of plants and vegetation, each with a determined size and proportion. The durian tree with its sturdy trunk is in harmony with its large and thorny fruit. The rice stalk is also harmonious and suitable for its fruit with stalks and the soil for its growth. Likewise, other plants are created by Allah in a balanced, harmonious, and appropriate manner with the climate, the condition of the area, and the needs of humans or animals where it grows. Meanwhile, the difference in the area and soil where a tree grows will cause differences in the taste and size of its fruit. The sugar element in sugarcane is different from the sugar element in coconut water, and its sweetness is different from mangoes and oranges. The salak fruit, when it is still a bud, is surrounded by sharp thorns, but after it ripens, it is as if the thorns reveal themselves, making it easy for humans to take the sweet-tasting fruit. The papaya bud tastes bitter when it is still small, so humans do not want to take and eat it. The bigger the bud, the less bitter it tastes, and the closer humans get to it. After it ripens, the fruit is picked and becomes a favorite food. Thus, Allah creates something with a certain size and proportion, so that seeing the perfection of His creation will increase the faith in the hearts of those who want to think and increase the belief that Allah is the Most Perfect.

Allah SWT says:

"And He it is who causes to grow gardens, [both] trellised and untrellised, and palm trees and crops of different [kinds of] food and olives and pomegranates, similar and dissimilar. Eat of [each] when it bears fruit and give its due [zakah] on the day of its harvest. And be not excessive. Indeed, He does not like those who commit excess." (al-An'am/6: 14)
text.20:
This verse explains Allah SWT's infinite blessings upon mankind, namely that He has created various necessities of life for humans. He has created fertile land that can be planted with useful crops that are essential for them. He created water that can be drunk and that gives life to plants. He also created birds that fly in the sky that can be caught and made into delicious and tasty food. He created the sea in which live various kinds of fish that can be eaten, as well as pearls and minerals needed by humans and which become a source of livelihood. The vast sea can be navigated by humans to all corners of the world. He is the One who created all kinds of sources of pleasure for mankind.

Allah SWT also created animals and other living creatures whose sustenance is guaranteed by Allah. Allah has also made it easy for humans to obtain all sources of necessities of life, which can be processed into clothing, food, medicine, and so on.

Allah also made children and grandchildren on earth as comforters and continuers of human life. Some people become servants or helpers, and others become masters or superiors. Allah also created pets and pleasures.

This verse is a reminder to humans that children, helpers, and livestock are guaranteed sustenance by Allah.
text.21:
This verse explains that the source of everything in this universe is Allah's creation. Everything originates from Allah's treasures or reserves, both in the form of natural resources (SDA) and human resources (SDM). Everything on earth and within it was created by Allah for humans. Humans are tasked by Allah to manage, benefit from, and preserve it. This is affirmed by Allah in Surah Hud/11 verse 61:

"He has produced you from the earth and settled you in it, so ask forgiveness of Him and then repent to Him. Indeed, my Lord is near and responsive." (Hud/11: 61)

To be able to derive great benefit from the available natural resources (SDA), humans need to develop the capabilities and skills of their human resources (SDM) by mastering various sciences and technologies. Then, to truly extract these natural resources, capital is needed. With a combination of natural resources, human skills, and sufficient capital, humans can obtain sustenance from Allah for their prosperity and well-being. This is in accordance with *sunatullah*, which is that only those who strive and work hard to seek it are given sustenance.

Striving and working hard to obtain sustenance from Allah's treasures must also be accompanied by the responsibility to preserve (conserve) wealth and natural resources, and not to damage or destroy them. Therefore, at the end of verse 61 of Surah Hud, Allah reminds humans to always ask for forgiveness and repent to Allah, and to stop actions that damage the natural order that has been determined in *sunatullah*. This can be understood through knowledge of science and technology.

A good human being according to Islamic teachings is one who can carry out tasks well in worship and *khilafah* (carrying out the task of leadership and good management of nature). He obtains sustenance by working and striving in a good and earnest manner, not by damaging and becoming a burden to others.

The Hadith of the Prophet saw narrated by al-Hakim has provided guidance, including:

From Rifaah bin Rafi that the Prophet saw was asked, "Which endeavor is the best?" The Messenger of Allah said, "A person's endeavor that is done with his hands and all *mabrur* trade (trade that is clean and does not contain elements of deception, coercion, etc.)." (Narrated by al-Hakim)

According to this hadith, good sustenance is the result of good work or effort from the person himself (not a gift from others), and the result of *mabrur* trade. What is meant by *mabrur* trade is trade that is carried out fairly, with mutual consent between the seller and the buyer, without coercion and without falsehood. Allah says:

"O you who have believed, do not consume one another's wealth unjustly but only [in lawful] business through mutual consent. And do not kill yourselves [or one another]. Indeed, Allah is to you ever Merciful." (an-Nisa'/4: 29)

Enjoying sustenance from one's own efforts and sweat or the results of trade is an honorable way as a Muslim, not because of gifts and compassion from others and not because of efforts prohibited by religion, such as taking rights, or trading by coercion or trickery.

Allah is Most Just and Most Wise in giving sustenance to His servants. This means giving with a certain measure, according to the needs, circumstances, abilities, and efforts of that person. Thus, in the giving of sustenance, Allah's love for His servants is reflected. Allah swt says:

"Say, "To whom belongs whatever is in the heavens and earth?" Say, "To Allah." He has decreed upon Himself mercy." (al-An'am/6: 12)

The bestowal of Allah's grace and blessings upon His servants is mentioned in the Qur'an with the word *anzala* (sent down), as mentioned in His other words:

"...And He has sent down for you eight mates of livestock..." (az-Zumar/39: 6)

And Allah swt says:

"...And We sent down iron, wherein is great military strength and benefits for the people..." (al-hadid/57: 25)

Something is said to be sent down when it moves from a high place to a low place, both in the literal and figurative sense. Therefore, from this verse, it can be understood that blessings and grace come from Allah, the Most High and Most Rich, bestowed upon creatures who are lower than Him. All creatures depend their entire lives and the continuation of their lives on Allah's blessings and grace. Thus, it is an obligation for every creature to be grateful for Allah's blessings and grace by submitting to Him.
text.22:
Allah explains some of the blessings that are in His treasures, namely that He has blown the wind to fertilize, develop, and pollinate plants. The growth, development, and pollination of plants through the wind means:

1. Allah blows the wind that carries clouds containing rain. The longer the wind-blown cloud, the heavier and darker it becomes, until it turns into a thick, dark cloud.

Regarding the process of rain formation, here is an explanation based on scientific studies. To explain the occurrence of rain, it must be seen in a complete water cycle. All the water that evaporates, whether from streams, rivers or the sea, forms water vapor in the atmosphere. This vapor rises and cools as it reaches higher altitudes in the atmosphere. If there are many gases in the atmosphere, it will condense into groups of gases called clouds. If the cloud is blown by the wind so that it gathers together, and rises to a higher part of the atmosphere, then the water vapor will turn into ice droplets. Dust, or anything that evaporates, may be trapped by water vapor or ice droplets. Thus, the volume and weight of the ice that forms will increase.

When clouds become colder due to lower atmospheric temperatures, water becomes solid (ice) and falls, initially as very small ice droplets, which usually melt before reaching the ground. Thus, water droplets will fall to earth as rain. In some high mountains or in cold parts of the world, this ice does not melt before reaching the ground, so it falls in the form of snow or ice.

Then from the cloudy sky comes rain that wets the surface of the earth, so that the soil that was originally dry becomes fertile. Plants and crops grow and develop, then flower, bud, and bear fruit. Some of the fruit can only be used by humans and animals, while others grow and develop again to continue their offspring and maintain their species from extinction. Some plants develop by planting parts of their stems. With watering from rainwater, the planted stem will grow and develop.

Scientifically, it can be explained that rainwater droplets contain revitalizing substances commonly known as "surface tension droplets". These elements are obtained from the surface layer of the sea, which is commonly called the "micro layer," which evaporates. On the outer layer of rainwater droplets, many organic litters are found originating from the decomposition process of microscopic algae and zooplankton. Some of these litters collect and absorb several elements, such as phosphorus, magnesium and potassium, which are rarely found in seawater. These litters also contain heavy metals such as copper, zinc, cobalt and iron. Land plants, and also life in the sea itself, will obtain most of the mineral salts and other elements needed for their lives along with the arrival of rainwater.

The salts that fall with rainwater are a miniature of the fertilizers commonly used in agriculture (NPK elements, etc.). Heavy metals in the air that are carried down by rainwater will form elements that increase productivity during plant growth and fruiting. Thus, rain is a very important source of fertilizer. Experts estimate that with the fertilizer contained in rainwater droplets alone, in 100 years, nutrient-poor soil can collect all the elements needed for trees to grow. Forests also grow and obtain their necessities of life from all the chemicals that come from the sea. In this way, it is estimated that every year, around 150 million tons of fertilizer falls to earth.

The process of the wind blowing clouds, until it becomes rain that wets the surface of the earth, reviving dead land, is explained by the word of Allah swt:

And it is He who sends the winds as good tidings before His mercy (rain). And We send down from the sky pure water. (al-Furqan/25: 48)

2. Allah swt blows the wind that carries pollen from various flowers. Then the male pollen lands on the flower pistil, so that pollination occurs which produces fruit buds, and the fruits become ripe, tasting delicious and pleasant for humans, and the seeds can grow and bear fruit in other places.

According to scientific studies, the verse above seems to give an indication of the process of a botanical phenomenon known as pollination or fertilization. In open-seeded plants (gymnosperms), pollination or fertilization is the event of pollen falling on the micropyle which is directly connected to the ovule. Meanwhile, in closed-seeded plants (Angiosperms), pollination or fertilization is the event of pollen falling from the stamen to the stigma. Pollination is then followed by fertilization. This is the process of marriage in the botanical world (plants).

Pollination requires an intermediary or vector. Based on the intermediary or vector, the pollination process is grouped into pollination by wind, water, or animals/insects. The sentence in the verse above which reads 'We have blown the wind to pollinate' indicates the event of pollination by means of wind, which in scientific language is known as anemophily or anemogamy.

3. The wind can clean dirt and dust that lands on the stems and leaves of plants, so that the plants can breathe easily and grow bigger, and the leaves can easily absorb sunlight which adds to their strength and fertility.

This gives a lesson on how humans make artificial pollination (al-talqih al-sina'i) on various kinds of flower and fruit trees. In this way, flowers with abundant fruit can be produced. Even with cross-breeding between several types of fruit, more beautiful and more colorful flowers can be produced, as well as fruits that are more delicious or larger in size.

From artificial pollination in plants, humans can then develop artificial pollination in several livestock animals such as cows, goats, horses, and others. This artificial pollination produces livestock that is larger and has more meat, and is more resistant to disease. This is the case if humans want to learn from Allah's guidance in the verses of the Al-Qur'an.

Another blessing of Allah swt that is related to the water that He sends down from the sky as mentioned in this verse is: Allah sends down rain from the sky, then that water is made for humans as a drink that can quench thirst, as Allah swt says:

Have you seen the water that you drink? Is it you who brought it down from the clouds, or is it We who bring it down? If We willed, We could make it bitter, so why are you not grateful? (al-Waqi'ah/56: 68-70)

And the word of Allah swt:

And it is He who sends the winds as good tidings before His mercy (rain). And We send down from the sky pure water, that We may bring to life thereby a dead land and give it as drink to many livestock and men that We have created. (al-Furqan/25: 48-49)

In this verse, it is emphasized that Allah regulates when rain is sent down and in which area according to His will. However, humans are tasked with regulating the use and storage of water on earth so that rain, which is a blessing, does not turn into a disaster. By His will, Allah bestows water upon humans, so that they can drink, wash, irrigate rice fields and fields, and give drink to livestock. The water irrigates rivers, lakes, and oceans that can be sailed by humans and become one of the sources of sustenance and life that never runs out. If Allah swt wills, He stores the water in the ground or in the bowels of the earth which can be dug and pumped by humans who need it, especially during the dry season. This is explained by Allah swt in His other words

And We send down water from the sky in a measured amount, and We cause it to remain in the earth, and indeed, We are able to take it away. (al-Mu'minun/23: 18)

And His word:

Do you not see that Allah sends down rain from the sky and makes it flow as springs [and rivers] in the earth; then He produces thereby crops of different colors; then they dry and you see them turning yellow; then He makes them [scattered] debris. Indeed in that is a reminder for those of understanding. (az-Zumar/39: 21)
text.23:
In this verse, Allah affirms that He is the One who gives life to humans if He wills, and He is also the One who causes them to die if He wills.

Furthermore, as explained by Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari in his tafsir, if all that lives has died, then at that time only Allah will be alive, because only He is eternal. Then Allah resurrects mankind to be weighed and accounted for their deeds, as Allah swt says:

"There is no god but He. He gives life and causes death. (He is) your Lord and the Lord of your forefathers." (ad-Dukhan/44: 8)

Verse 23 is concluded with the expression *wa nahnul-waritsun* (and We are the inheritors). Al-Qasimi in his tafsir *Mahasin at-Ta'wil* explains that We (are the inheritors) means that We are the ones who remain and receive or possess all that has been left behind by the people who have died. The term *waris* (inheritor) is also used by the Prophet in his supplication:

"And make him an inheritor from us." (Narrated by at-Tirmidzi from Ibn Umar)
text.24:
In a narration conveyed by at-Tirmizi and al-Hakim from Ibn Abbas, it is explained that this verse was revealed in connection with a beautiful woman who prayed following the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him). Therefore, some companions who wanted to pray following the Prophet (peace be upon him) moved forward to the first row so they wouldn't be able to see the woman. They were worried that seeing the woman's face would invalidate their prayer. Meanwhile, some other companions moved back to the rear, hoping to see the woman's face during the bowing (ruku') through their armpits. So this verse was revealed, rebuking the actions of those companions. Allah SWT knows the intentions of the companions who moved to the first row and the intentions of the companions who moved to the back row.

This shows that among the companions of the Prophet, as human beings, some were very good, very careful in preserving their prayers so as not to see a beautiful woman for fear of invalidating their prayer. However, there were also those who actually wanted to see the beautiful woman. This is natural and human, and has not yet reached the level of sinful acts that violate religion.

Even though this verse was revealed with the above event, it also encompasses Allah SWT's knowledge of everything implied and etched in a person's heart.

Based on this *sabab nuzul* (reason for revelation), Ibn 'Abbas interprets *al-mustaqdimin wal-musta'khirin* as the virtue of praying in the front row compared to praying in the back row. Some scholars interpret it as knowledge of humans who were created first, humans now, and humans who will be created later.

Another meaning of *al-mustaqdimin wal-musta'khirin* is that Allah knows the past and the future of mankind. There are also scholars who interpret *al-mustaqdimin* as those who hasten to do good, and *al-musta'khirin* as the opposite.

In this verse, Allah SWT affirms that He is the Almighty who knows all that is past, along with the events that have occurred from the greatest to the smallest. He knows what exists now, and knows what will happen in the future; not a single event is unknown to Him.
text.25: This verse explains that Allah SWT will gather all of humanity in the afterlife, both those who came before, those who are present, and those who will come in the future. All of their deeds will be weighed, none will be left unweighed, because none of those deeds escape the knowledge of Allah. Then He will give rewards and retribution to people according to the deeds they have done. Allah is All-Wise and All-Knowing of everything.
text.26:
This verse explains that after perfecting the form of His creation, Allah then breathed His spirit into it. According to scientists, the word *hama'* (black mud) in this verse indicates the involvement of water molecules (H2O) in the process of forming molecules that support the life process. As is known, 'water is the medium for the occurrence of a chemical/biochemical reaction process to form a new molecule. The phrase "which was given form" indicates that the biochemical reactions that occur in the aqueous medium have transformed the elements, which were originally 'only atoms, into an organic molecule, whose structure and shape are specific, such as amino acids or nucleotides.

In another verse, Allah SWT explains the creation of man:

He created man from dried clay [like] pottery, And He created the jinn from a smokeless flame of fire. (ar-Rahman/55: 14-15)

Scientifically, pottery is a type of porcelain, which in a chemical reaction process can be used as a catalyst for the occurrence of a polymerization process. The phrase "dried clay [like] pottery" may indicate the occurrence of a polymerization process or a chain elongation reaction of molecules from amino acids into proteins or from nucleotides into polynucleotides, including the molecule Deoxyribonucleic Acid (DNA), a material that makes up the gene structure of living things.

And the word of Allah SWT:

[Mention] when your Lord said to the angels, "Indeed, I am going to create a human being from clay. So when I have proportioned him and breathed into him of My [created] soul, then fall down to him in prostration." (shad/38: 71-72)

What is meant by *insan* (human being) in this verse is Adam a.s., who is the father of all mankind. Some *tafsir* scholars are of the opinion that the Adam mentioned in this verse is not the first human, because before that Allah SWT had created thousands of Adams. But Prophet Adam was the first prophet who was given the task of preaching to people to follow the right path.

The *hadith* of the Prophet explains the process of Adam's creation. Prophet Muhammad SAW said:

Indeed, Allah 'Azza wa Jalla created Adam from a handful of soil taken from all kinds of soil, so the children of Adam were born according to the amount of soil. Among them are red, some are black, and some are between the two colors. Some are easy, some are difficult, some are good, and some are bad. (Narrated by Ahmad and Muslim from 'Aisyah)
text.27:
Allah SWT explains that He created the jinn from scorching fire before creating Adam. Only Allah knows the true nature of this fire. In accordance with the hadith above, which states that human nature varies according to the state of the soil that forms them, this can be taken as evidence that the nature of the jinn corresponds to the nature of their origin.

Just as fire is hot, so too is the nature of the jinn. Fire can suddenly flare up and become large, then suddenly diminish and become small. Likewise, the jinn are hasty, quick to anger, like to play and hurt humans, sometimes submit and obey Allah, but immediately rebel and disobey Allah. Humans are in accordance with the nature of their origin, such as being patient, liking to grow, develop, maintain and seek good things, liking to heed commands, having a nature of submission and obedience, even though sometimes they disobey Allah because they submit to and follow their desires.

In a hadith qudsi, the origin of angels, jinn, and humans is mentioned based on a narration from 'Aisyah:

Allah SWT said, "I created the angels from light, and I created the jinn from a flame of fire, and Adam was created as has been explained to you." (Narrated by Ahmad and Muslim from 'Aisyah)

The jinn are among Allah's creatures. Like other creatures of Allah, some jinn are obedient to Allah and some are disobedient, as Allah SWT says:

And among us are righteous [people] and among us are [others] not so; we have been of different ways. (al-Jinn/72: 11)

The jinn are given burdens and responsibilities by Allah, just as humans are given burdens and responsibilities; they develop and have offspring. Only humans cannot see them, while they can see humans.

Therefore, some jinn are submissive and obedient to Allah, and some are disobedient like Iblis. Allah SWT says:

And among us are Muslims [in submission to Allah], and among us are the deviators. And whoever has become Muslim - those have sought out the right course. (al-Jinn/72: 14)

According to Ibn 'Abbas, what is meant by *jan* (jinn) in this verse is the father of all jinn, just as Adam is the father of all humans. While Iblis is the father of all devils. The jinn also eat, drink, live, and die like humans.

Allah SWT says:

O children of Adam, let not Satan tempt you as he removed your parents from Paradise, stripping them of their clothing to show them their private parts. Indeed, he sees you, he and his tribe, from where you do not see them. Indeed, We have made the devils allies for those who do not believe. (al-A'raf/7: 27)
text.28:
In this verse, Allah swt commands Prophet Muhammad saw to remind his people, when Allah told the angels about His intention to create Adam. He would create man from dry clay derived from black mud, and when He had perfected its form in the best way, He would breathe into it a spirit of His creation and command the angels and Iblis to prostrate to him as a sign of respect.

This command of Allah was carried out by the angels with obedience and reverence, except for Iblis. He refused to prostrate to Adam, because he felt he was of a higher rank than Adam. He was created from fire, while Adam was created from clay.

Most commentators (ahli tafsir) are of the opinion that the event of Adam's creation and Iblis's denial of Allah's command, as well as the angels' obedience and sincerity in carrying out the command, illustrate the nature of these three kinds of Allah's creatures. Angels were created as creatures who are always submissive and obedient to Allah's commands, never denying them in the slightest. Therefore, Allah made the angels guardians and regulators of the earth with His permission, and commanded them to be submissive to Adam and his descendants.

As for humans, they are creatures of Allah consisting of two elements, namely the physical element and the spiritual element. The combination of these two elements causes humans to have the potential to benefit from the entire earth with the knowledge that Allah has bestowed upon them. Various possibilities are open to him to act and work to fulfill and complete the needs he requires by digging and taking them from Allah swt's treasures.

With self-potential and knowledge, humans can utilize water, air, minerals, plants, livestock, the orbits of planets, electrical power, atomic power, and so on. Thus, the superiority of humans over angels and devils is apparent, as can be understood from Allah's answer to the angels when Adam a.s. was about to be created by Allah. Allah swt said:

And (mention, O Muhammad), when your Lord said to the angels, "Indeed, I will make upon the earth a successive authority." They said, "Will You place upon it one who causes corruption therein and sheds blood, while we declare Your praise and sanctify You?" Allah said, "Indeed, I know that which you do not know." (al-Baqarah/2: 30)

Above, Iblis's denial, who refused to follow Allah's command to prostrate to Adam, has been explained. The various reasons put forward by Iblis in connection with his denial were also explained. Iblis's attitude shows his ignorance and wickedness, because:

1. He opposed the command of his Lord, as understood from his answer.

2. He put forward very weak reasons. These reasons show his own ignorance.

3. He refused to follow Allah's command by saying that he was better than Adam.

4. The reason given that he was better than Adam was his own opinion without any reason acceptable to the mind.

text.30:
In this verse, Allah swt commands Prophet Muhammad saw to remind his people, when Allah told the angels about His intention to create Adam. He would create man from dry clay derived from black mud, and when He had perfected his form in the best possible way, He would breathe into him a spirit of His creation and command the angels and Iblis to prostrate to him as a sign of respect.

As for humans, they are creatures of Allah consisting of two elements, namely the physical element and the spiritual element. The combination of these two elements causes humans to have the potential to benefit from the entire earth with the knowledge that Allah has bestowed upon them. Various possibilities are open to them to act and work to fulfill and complete the needs they require by digging and taking them from Allah swt's treasures.

With self-potential and knowledge, humans can utilize water, air, minerals, plants, livestock, planetary orbits, electrical power, atomic power, and so on. text.34:
Allah SWT answered Iblis' denial by commanding him to leave Paradise or the company of angels. As a result of that denial, Iblis was distanced from Allah's mercy, subjected to punishment, and continuously receives His curse until the Day of Reckoning.

In another verse of Allah, it is explained that Iblis was expelled from Paradise because he was arrogant and belonged to the ranks of the humiliated. Allah SWT says:

"(Allah) said, "Descend from Paradise, for it is not for you to be arrogant therein. So get out! Indeed, you are of the disgraced." (al-A'raf/7: 13)

After hearing Allah's decision, Iblis declared that he accepted the punishment. However, he pleaded with God to extend his life until the day when humans are resurrected from the graves. Iblis' request was granted by Allah, and he will continue to live until the end of time, until the trumpet is blown, resurrecting humans from the graves.
