text.39:
Because he had been cursed and damned by Allah by being distanced from His blessings and made astray and humiliated, Iblis pleaded that Allah give him the opportunity to mislead the descendants of Adam by making evil deeds appear good in their eyes. Thus, it would attract their hearts so that without realizing it, they would commit those evil deeds. However, this does not apply to sincere and pious servants, who cannot be turned away from the truth.

According to some *mufasir*, after being cursed, Iblis did not ask for forgiveness from Allah, but instead swore to deceive and mislead the descendants of Adam until the Day of Judgment, except for the righteous and sincere servants. They cannot be deceived and misled because of the strength of their faith, based on the word of Allah swt:

(Iblis) said, "By Your might, I will surely mislead them all, except, among them, Your chosen servants." (Shad/38: 82-83)

This oath is truly carried out and realized by Iblis with all the abilities he possesses, as Allah swt says:

(Iblis) said, "Because You have put me in error, I will surely sit in wait for them on Your straight path. Then I will come to them from before them and from behind them and on their right and on their left, and You will not find most of them grateful [to You]." (al-A'raf/7: 16-17)

Allah swt states that Iblis can fulfill the target of his oath by misleading most of humanity. Allah says:

And Iblis had already confirmed through them his assumption, so they followed him, except for a faction of believers. (Saba/34: 20)

Those who follow Satan and Iblis make him their leader, as Allah swt says:

O children of Adam, let not Satan tempt you as he removed your parents from Paradise, stripping them of their clothing to show them their private parts. Indeed, he and his tribe see you from where you do not see them. Indeed, We have made the devils allies for those who do not believe. (al-A'raf/7: 27)

text.41:
Allah SWT rebukes Iblis with this verse, stating that not everything Iblis declared is true because he cannot mislead His righteous servants. This is what Allah calls the straight path. He rewards all the good deeds of a servant and punishes all the bad deeds of a person.

To dispel any doubts that might be understood from the previous verses, Allah SWT affirms in this verse that none of Allah's sincere and believing servants can be controlled by Satan. All of them have been granted *taufik* (divine guidance) to believe, carry out Allah's commands, and abstain from all His prohibitions. No temptation will affect their faith. This is affirmed by Allah in His other words:

And Satan will say when the matter has been concluded, "Indeed, Allah had promised you the promise of truth. And I promised you, but I betrayed you. But I had no authority over you except that I invited you, and you responded to me. So do not blame me; but blame yourselves. I cannot help you, nor can you help me. Indeed, I disbelieved in your associating me with Allah [in worship] before." Indeed, for the wrongdoers is a painful punishment. (Ibrahim/14: 22)

Allah SWT says:

Indeed, he has no authority over those who have believed and rely upon their Lord. His authority is only over those who take him as an ally and those who associate others with Him. (an-Nahl/16: 99-100)

Then, Allah SWT threatens Satan and his followers with Hell as retribution for all the kinds of evil they have committed.

Allah SWT explains the state of Hell that will be inhabited by those who are astray, which consists of seven levels. Each level is inhabited by people whose sins and punishments correspond to the level of evil they have committed.

According to Ibn Juraij, Hell has seven levels: first, Jahannam; second, Ladha; third, Huthamah; fourth: Sair; fifth, Saqar; sixth, Jahim; and seventh, Hawiyah. Each level is occupied according to the degree of their sins.

From these verses, it can be understood that humans have two prominent characteristics: first, they have a nature that likes to follow desires and is influenced by worldly life with all kinds of enchanting pleasures. These are the polytheists who are easily influenced by Satan. Second, humans who have faith in Allah and His Messenger, their souls are pure and noble, their relationship with Allah is very close, and they love goodness. This group cannot be influenced by Satan because their hearts have turned to Allah SWT.

text.45:
This verse explains that those who are righteous will be placed in Paradise with gardens that have several flowing springs. In another verse of Allah SWT, the characteristics of Paradise promised to the righteous are also explained, as in the word of Allah:

The description of Paradise promised to the righteous is that in it are rivers of water that are not altered, rivers of milk the taste of which never changes, rivers of wine delicious to those who drink, and rivers of purified honey. In it for them is [fruit] of every kind and forgiveness from their Lord. [Are] those equal to those who abide eternally in the Fire and are given to drink scalding water that will sever their intestines? (Muhammad/47: 15)

What is meant by the righteous are those who protect themselves from the punishment of Allah by carrying out the commands of Allah and avoiding His prohibitions.
text.46: This verse explains that those who are pious are welcomed into Paradise. There, they will be safe, prosperous, secure, and peaceful, and there will be no fear, sadness, or anxiety. Nothing will disturb their peace of mind, and no calamity will afflict them; rather, Allah will bestow upon them unending blessings.
text.47:
Allah promises to remove from the hearts of the inhabitants of Paradise all kinds of grudges, hatred, and envy that had been harbored during their lives in the world, and to make them live as brothers and sisters in love and affection. They will always rejoice together and sit facing each other on carpets spread out.

It is narrated by al-Qasim and Abu Umamah, who said, "Initially, when the people of Paradise enter Paradise, they still carry what has been stored in their hearts during their lives in the world, such as envy and resentment, until they sit facing their friends on couches in Paradise. Then Allah removes everything stored in their hearts." Then Abu Umamah recited this verse.

The state of the inhabitants of Paradise is also explained in Allah SWT's words:

*On thrones of woven gold and inlaid with jewels, reclining on them, facing each other. There will circulate among them young boys never altering in youth, with goblets, pitchers, and cups [filled] from a flowing spring. No headache will they have therefrom, nor will they be intoxicated - and fruit of what they select - and the meat of fowl, from whatever they desire. And [for them are] fair women with large, [beautiful] eyes, like pearls well-protected.* (al-Waqi'ah/56: 15-23)
text.48:
The inhabitants of Paradise never feel tired or weary, because they are no longer burdened by various efforts to fulfill their basic needs. Everything they desire is readily available, they only need to utilize it. They never worry about being moved to a place they dislike because they are eternal in Paradise. They will continue to experience the pleasures and delights that are already available.

In another verse, Allah swt describes the state within Paradise:

"Who has settled us in a home of perpetuity by His grace. Therein no fatigue will touch us, nor will weariness touch us [therein]." (Fathir/35: 35)

A hadith of the Prophet saw explains the state of Paradise:

The Messenger of Allah saw said, "Indeed, Allah commanded me to give Khadijah the glad tidings of a house (that she will inhabit) in Paradise made of reeds, there is no difficulty in it, and there is no weariness in it." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from 'Abdullah bin Aufa)

When asked, "What envy?" Ali bin Abi Husain replied, "The envy of ignorance, namely the attitude of hostility between Bani Tamim (Abu Bakar's tribe) and Bani Umayyah." When Abu Bakar suffered from back pain, Ali heated his hand and with his hand he heated Abu Bakar's back, then this verse was revealed.

This verse explains the situation of Prophet Ibrahim when unknown and uninvited guests arrived. The guests entered and offered greetings. Because he did not recognize his guests, Prophet Ibrahim said that he was afraid of them. The reason for Ibrahim's fear is explained in another verse. Allah SWT says:

"Then when he saw that their hands did not reach for it, he mistrusted them and felt fear of them. They (the angels) said, "Fear not, indeed, we have been sent to the people of Lut." (Hud/11: 70)

According to this verse, Ibrahim was afraid of his guests because they refused to eat the roasted calf meat that was presented to them. text.53:
Seeing that Ibrahim was afraid, the guests told him not to be afraid because the purpose of their arrival was to convey good news from Allah, that he would be granted a righteous son. In another verse of Allah it is mentioned that the son who would be granted would have an important position in the future.

Allah says:

And We gave him good tidings of Isaac, a prophet among the righteous. (as-Saffat/37: 112)

Ibrahim was amazed at the good news conveyed by the angels. He almost did not believe it, especially since the news was conveyed by someone he did not know and at that time Ibrahim and his wife Sarah were old. According to custom, people who are old can no longer have children. Of course, he considered the news strange, especially since his wife was also barren.

Ibrahim's guests emphasized that the news they conveyed was true, because the birth of a desired son was a blessing from Allah given to His servants. Allah is able to bestow that blessing on whomever He wills. He is also able to create or bring about something that deviates from His own sunnah.

After hearing the explanation of the angels, Ibrahim became convinced that the strange guests were no ordinary guests. They were angels of Allah sent to him to convey good news. Because of that conviction, Ibrahim immediately replied to their words that no one despairs of the mercy of his Lord except those who are astray. In a hadith of the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) it is explained how abundant and vast the blessings of Allah are:

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) said, "Indeed, Allah Almighty has created mercy, at that time He created one hundred mercies, then He withheld ninety-nine mercies, and released one mercy to all His creatures. If the disbeliever knew all the mercy that is with Allah, they would not despair of that mercy, and if the believer knew all kinds of torment that are with Allah Almighty, they would not feel safe from the fire of hell." (Narrated by al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah)

In this case, Ibrahim (peace be upon him) as a prophet and messenger of Allah certainly knew how abundant the mercy that is with Allah is. Therefore, he believed in the truth conveyed by the angels.

text.61:
After the angels delivered the good news to Ibrahim (peace be upon him) about Allah's gift to him in the form of the birth of a son and the news of the destruction of the disbelieving people of Lut, they left Ibrahim's house and headed towards the city of Sodom, the land where the people of Lut lived, located in the Jordan region, to carry out the task that Allah had entrusted to them.

Their sudden arrival at his house was completely unexpected by Lut (peace be upon him), and he did not know at all who these guests were. This is reflected in Lut's statement when welcoming his guests, "Indeed, you are people unknown." In another verse of Allah, Lut's anxiety and ignorance about his people are also described.

Allah says:

"And when Our messengers (the angels) came to Lut, he was distressed because of them and felt helpless to protect them." (al-'Ankabut/29: 33)

From this verse, it is understood that the reason for Prophet Lut's worry and anxiety was the sudden and unexpected arrival of these guests at his house. The angels disguised themselves as handsome men, who were very attractive to the people of Lut who enjoyed practicing homosexuality. Usually, if such men came, the people of Lut would come in droves to his house and force Lut to hand over his guests to them. If Lut (peace be upon him) knew for certain that those who came were angels, he would not have been worried because he believed that the angels could defend and protect themselves from their actions.

text.63:
The angels explained the purpose of their arrival to Lut (peace be upon him). They came to deliver bad news, namely the torment that would befall his people who had denied and rejected him.

In this verse, the angels' answer is mentioned, "Indeed, we have come to you with the torment which they were always denying." Even with the words, "We have come to punish them." The intention of the angels' answer with such words was to affirm the truth of the threat that Lut had been conveying to his people all this time. Prophet Lut (peace be upon him) always warned his people to follow and embrace the religion he had conveyed and to acknowledge his prophethood. If they persisted in disbelief, they would be afflicted with Allah's torment. They responded to Lut's call and statement with mockery. They did not believe in the oneness and power of Allah, who could punish those who disbelieved. They even challenged Lut to hasten the promised torment.

Then the angels affirmed to Lut that the purpose of their arrival was to carry out the task that Allah Almighty had entrusted to them, to deliver torment to his people. This task would certainly be carried out, and everything they said was true, because they themselves were angels who never disobeyed Allah's commands.

After that, the angels gave instructions to Lut (peace be upon him) regarding the steps he and his followers should take to avoid the coming torment of Allah. Lut, along with his family and his people who had believed, were ordered to leave the land immediately at the end of the night. Lut (peace be upon him) was asked to walk behind his followers, so that he could manage and defend himself from the attacks of his people who were chasing from behind. This was also intended so that Lut (peace be upon him) could encourage his followers to walk as quickly as possible, because the torment that would befall them was near, and he could pay attention to his people who did not want to continue the journey. Furthermore, the angels ordered that none of Lut's followers should look back when they heard the thunder that destroyed. Thus, they could not see the terrible events that could damage and shake their souls, so that they would be safe and their faith would be strengthened until they reached the safe place they were heading to.

In this verse, it is mentioned that Lut should depart with his family and his loyal people. Then the angels reinforced the command and prohibition by saying, "Continue your journey to the place you have been commanded to." According to a narration, the place commanded in this verse is the land of Sham (Syria).

In Surah Hud, the story of Lut is narrated according to the sequence of events that occurred, while in this surah it is narrated in a jumping manner, not according to the actual sequence of events. The difference in the way this story is told is because the purpose of Allah conveying this story in the two surahs is also different. If it is connected with the previous verses, then the purpose of conveying the story of Lut in Surah Hud is to strengthen the hearts of Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his companions, in conveying the religion of Allah and declaring the oneness and power of Allah Almighty who must be worshiped. The messengers sent by Allah from ancient times always faced challenges and threats from their people, but they remained steadfast and patient in carrying out the tasks entrusted to them by Allah. Meanwhile, the purpose of the story of Lut with his people in Surah Al-Hijr is to explain to the believers the mercy and blessings of Allah that they have received. Also, the blessings that were received by those who believed in the messengers sent by Allah to them in ancient times. Among them are the blessings that have been bestowed upon Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) in the form of sons that he always longed for, and the blessings that have been bestowed upon Prophet Lut and his followers. Also, to explain the torment of Allah that has been inflicted upon those who disbelieve and reject the da'wah of the messenger who was sent to them.

In Surah Hud, the story of Lut is narrated according to the order of events that occurred, while in this surah it is narrated in a non-sequential manner, not according to the actual order of events. The difference in the way this story is told is because the purpose of Allah conveying this story in the two surahs is also different. If it is connected to the previous verses, then the purpose of telling the story of Lut in Surah Hud is to strengthen the hearts of Prophet Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him) and his companions in conveying the religion of Allah and declaring the oneness and power of Allah Almighty, who must be worshipped. The messengers sent by Allah from ancient times always faced challenges and threats from their people, but they remained steadfast and patient in carrying out the tasks entrusted to them by Allah. Meanwhile, the purpose of the story of Lut with his people in Surah Al-Hijr is to explain to the believers the mercy and blessings of Allah that they have received. Also, the blessings that were received by those who believed in the messengers sent by Allah to them in ancient times. Among them are the blessings that have been bestowed upon Prophet Ibrahim (peace be upon him) in the form of sons that he had always longed for, and the blessings that have been bestowed upon Prophet Lut and his followers. Also, to explain the torment of Allah that has been inflicted upon those who disbelieved and rejected the da'wah of the messenger who was sent to them.
text.66: This verse explains that before the arrival of the angels, Allah had revealed to Lut (peace be upon him) about the events that would occur before and after the punishment inflicted upon his people. Therefore, it can be understood that after the angels explained to Lut (peace be upon him) about the task Allah had assigned to them, and after hearing the angels' commands given to him, and in accordance with the revelation that Allah had sent down, he believed that the punishment that would be inflicted upon his people by the angels would truly happen. For that reason also, he diligently followed the commands and guidance given by the angels in an effort to save the believers from that terrible disaster.
text.67:
When the people of Lot, the inhabitants of Sodom, heard that Lot had received handsome guests, they rejoiced. Their evil lust arose to commit homosexuality with the guests, which was a bad habit they always practiced.

Seeing the behavior of his people, Lot, peace be upon him, said to them, "Indeed, the young men you are approaching and inviting to commit immoral acts are my guests. I must honor and respect my guests. Do not commit immoral acts with them, because your actions will bring shame upon me. Fear Allah, protect yourselves from His punishment, and do not rape them."

The people of Lot opposed and threatened Prophet Lot because of his words, saying, "Have we not forbidden you to protect guests who come here from the desires and actions we will take against them?"

The words of the people of Lot indicate that they always forced the guests who came at that time to be willing to commit homosexual acts with them. This vile act was forbidden by Lot. However, they ignored the prohibition, and even threatened Lot with punishment if he continued to interfere in their affairs.

But Lot still warned them and offered them his daughters to marry, because that is in accordance with *sunatullah* (the natural law of God). He said, "O my people, marry my daughters. Do not marry those of the same sex as you, because marriage with those of the same sex is forbidden by Allah. Do what is lawful and in accordance with *sunatullah*. Allah deliberately created men and women so that they could marry and have children. If you continue to do so, you will not have descendants and the human race will become extinct from the face of the earth."

In this verse, Lot, peace be upon him, mentions "my daughters." What is meant is "his female followers" because a prophet usually refers to his people as his children, and the prophet's wife is the mother of his community, as Allah says:

The Prophet is more worthy of the believers than themselves, and his wives are [in the position of] their mothers. (al-Ahzab/33: 6)

If the wives of the Prophet are the mothers of the believers, then the Prophet himself is their father and all his people are his sons and daughters.

text.72:
This verse clarifies Allah SWT's affirmation to the Prophet Muhammad SAW that the homosexual and lesbian acts committed by the people of Lot were truly vile and misguided deeds, and therefore must be avoided and abandoned.

Arabs commonly swear by mentioning someone's age. In this verse, Allah SWT swears by the age and life of the Prophet Muhammad SAW, the purpose of which is to demonstrate the Prophet Muhammad SAW's virtue.

Some Quranic commentators (mufassirun) are of the opinion that those who swore in this verse were the angels. They stated that the actions of the people of Lot were excessive. However, this opinion is refuted by a narration (riwayat) which states that Allah SWT never swore by mentioning the ages of other prophets and messengers, except for the age of the Prophet Muhammad SAW. This is solely to demonstrate the virtue of the Prophet Muhammad.
text.73: This verse explains the punishment inflicted upon the people of Lot, to show the consequences of their actions. The punishment came in the early morning in the form of a thunderous sound that destroyed the city of Sodom. In another verse, it is mentioned that the punishment came at dawn and ended at sunrise.
text.75:
This verse explains the actions and behavior of the people of Lot, and how they were subsequently destroyed because of their deeds that contradicted the commands of Allah, the One God, the Almighty, who is merciful and compassionate to His believing servants, and punishes those who disbelieve in Him. Believers, who pay attention to the signs of Allah's power and greatness, take all of this as a lesson, as mentioned in the hadith:

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Beware of the insight (firasat) of the believers, for indeed he sees with the light of Allah," then he recited this surah. (Narrated by at-Tirmidhi and Ibn Jarir ath-Thabari from Abu Sa'id al-Khudri)

This *firasat* is of two kinds:

1. An impression and feeling that Allah (SWT) places in the hearts of righteous people. The ability given to them to read facial expressions, behavior, and the condition of others.

2. *Firasat* that arises from experience, a noble life, and noble character.

It is also mentioned in the hadith:

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Indeed, Allah has servants who know people by signs." (Narrated by ath-Thabrani and al-Bazzar from Anas bin Malik)
text.76:
Allah SWT explains that the land of the people of Lot, which had been destroyed, was located on roads commonly traveled by people. Its ruins can be seen to this day by those who travel from Medina to Syria (Syam). This is affirmed by Allah SWT in another of His verses:

"And indeed, you (people of Makkah) pass by them in the morning, and at night. Then will you not understand?" (as-Saffat/37: 137-138)

The Arabs of Mecca usually conducted trade with Syria (Syam). They traveled in caravans. On their round trips from Mecca to Syria (Syam), they passed through the land of the people of Lot and could witness its remains.
text.77: Then Allah swt warned that the punishment He inflicted upon the people of Lot, causing their destruction, and the salvation of Lot and his followers, were signs of Allah's power and greatness. He will punish everyone who disbelieves and is disobedient, and reward those who believe in Him. As for the disbelievers, the event that destroyed the people of Lot was merely the result of a natural disaster. The existence of earthquakes, scorching heat throughout the year, and the emergence of epidemics are common occurrences in this world, and have no connection with human disobedience and disbelief in Allah swt.
text.78:
This verse explains that the inhabitants of the city of Aikah were a people who were unjust and disbelieving. The Prophet Shu'aib (peace be upon him) was sent to them, but they denied and rejected his message.

A hadith explains the relationship between the people of Aikah and the people of Madyan.

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him) said, "Indeed, the people of Madyan and the people of Aikah are two communities to whom Allah sent the Prophet Shu'aib." (Narrated by Ibn Mardawaih and Ibn 'Asakir)

The basic meaning of Aikah is forest, which then became the name of a country because the country had many forests. The country was located in the Madyan region.

The people of Aikah adhered to polytheistic beliefs, liked to ambush and rob people passing through their country, and were dishonest in weighing and measuring. The Prophet Shu'aib (peace be upon him) was sent to them, but they denied him.
text.79:
Because of their actions that violated Allah's prohibitions and ignored the call of the messenger, they were afflicted with torment in the form of scorching heat for seven days, without even a single cloud to provide shade. Allah then sent a cloud, and they sought shelter beneath it. Suddenly, from within the cloud, flames of fire burst forth, consuming them. In Surah al-A'raf/7: 91, it is explained that they were also struck by a terrible earthquake.

Then the earthquake struck them, and they lay dead, face down, in the ruins of their homes. (al-A'raf/7: 91)

Then Allah swt explains that the city of Sodom and the city of Aikah were two cities located close to each other, both situated on a road commonly traveled by people. In fact, the remnants of their civilization can still be seen and studied, so that they may serve as a lesson for those who are willing to use their minds.
text.80:
This verse explains that the inhabitants of the city of al-Hijr had denied the messengers. In this verse, the term "messengers" is used even though they only denied one messenger, namely Prophet Saleh (peace be upon him), because denying one messenger is the same as denying all of Allah's messengers. All the messengers sent by Allah brought the religion of *tauhid* (monotheism) and the same fundamental principles of religion. Even though they only denied one messenger, they had denied the *tauhid* and fundamental principles of religion brought by that messenger, which means they had denied all the messengers.

The city of al-Hijr was the residence of the people of Thamud, located between Mecca and Syria, near Wadi al-Qura. Prophet Saleh was sent to them and given a miracle as proof of his prophethood. Saleh declared his miracle in the form of a female camel that they recognized as proof of his prophethood. The camel was not to be disturbed or harmed. The amount of drinking water was determined in rotation, namely one day for the camel to drink and one day for all of them to drink. But they refused to follow Saleh's provisions, and they even slaughtered the camel.

But they refused to follow Saleh's provisions, and they even slaughtered the camel.
text.82:
The people of Thamud were a people strong and mighty in body. They carved mountains of stone to make their homes, so their city was called "al-Hijr," which means the city of stone mountains. Because of their wickedness, Allah inflicted upon them a punishment in the form of a loud, thunderous sound that destroyed them all. This severe punishment came in the morning on the fourth day of the days that Salih had designated for them to think. But they did not heed it, so they were buried in their homes, which were caves carved into the mountains of stone. Their situation is explained by Allah in another verse:

"Then the (awful) Blast overtook the wrongdoers, and they lay (dead), prostrate in their homes, As if they had never lived there. Verily, Thamud disbelieved in their Lord! So away with Thamud!" (Hud/11: 67-68)

The people of Thamud could not escape the punishment of Allah in the slightest. Their physical strength, their ability to carve mountains to make houses that seemed like strong fortresses, and their wealth and large numbers were of no benefit. All were destroyed along with them, as if the land had never been inhabited by humans.

Regarding the severity of the punishment experienced by the people of Thamud, it is depicted in a hadith of the Prophet saw:

From Ibn Umar r.a. that the Prophet saw passed through the city of Hijr on his way to the battle of Tabuk, then he lowered his head and quickened his pace, saying to his companions, "Do not enter the houses of the people who were punished (the people of Thamud) unless you are weeping. If you are not weeping, then you should pretend to weep because you fear that you will be afflicted with punishment later as they were afflicted with punishment before." (Riwayat al-Bukhari)

If you are not weeping, then you should pretend to weep because you are afraid that you will be afflicted with punishment later as they were afflicted with punishment before." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)
text.85:
This verse explains that Allah created everything in the heavens and on earth, not to commit injustice and oppression against all inhabitants or creatures, as was done to disobedient people of the past. Allah created these things with purpose and intention, in accordance with Allah's knowledge and compassion for His creation. Similarly, the stories of past peoples are conveyed so that they can be taken as lessons, parables, and examples for those who want to believe in Allah's power and greatness.

Then, Allah SWT affirms that the Day of Judgment is certainly coming, without the slightest doubt, because at that time Allah will perfect the recompense for humans according to the deeds they have done. Good deeds will be rewarded with Paradise, while bad deeds will be punished with the torment of Hell.

Allah warns that if people do not want to believe in Allah and the Prophet Muhammad, and do not want to take lessons and experiences from what past communities have experienced, then the Messenger is commanded to turn away from them, and show good manners, high character, and forgive their unreasonable actions towards him.

This verse explains the attitudes that a *dai* (preacher) in particular, and all Muslims in general, must possess in conveying the religion of Allah and facing disobedient people. Muslims are only obligated to convey the religion of Allah, and are not required to force and make them (the disobedient) believe, as it is only Allah who determines a person's faith and disbelief.
text.86: Furthermore, Allah affirms that He is the One and Only God, the All-Creator, and the All-Knowing of everything, whether visible or invisible, manifest or hidden, and He is the All-Knowing of all that is in the hearts.
text.87:
This verse explains that Allah has revealed to the Prophet Muhammad "as-sab'ul matsani" (the seven verses that are repeatedly recited) and the Grand Qur'an. This verse does not explain what is meant by "as-sab'ul matsani" and "the Grand Qur'an." However, there is a hadith that explains that what is meant by as-sab'ul matsani and the Grand Qur'an is Surah al-Fatihah. The hadith is:

From Abi Said Al-Mu'alla, he said, "The Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, passed by me while I was praying, so he called me, and I did not come to him until I finished praying. Then I came to him, and the Prophet said, "Why did you not come to me?" I replied, "I was praying." He said, "Has Allah not said, "O you who have believed, respond to Allah and to the Messenger when he calls you?" Then he said, "Know! I will teach you the greatest surah in the Qur'an before I leave this mosque." So the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him, went to leave, then I reminded him, so he said, "Al-hamdu lillahi rabbil-'alamin is "as-sab'ul-matsani" and "the Grand Qur'an" that has been given to me." (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

In another hadith, the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said:

Ummul-Qur'an is as-sab'ul-matsani and the Grand Qur'an. (Narrated by al-Bukhari)

Many other sahih hadiths explain that as-sab'ul-matsani and the Grand Qur'an are other names for Surah al-Fatihah.

Some commentators are of the opinion that what is meant by as-sab'ul matsani in the verse above is as-sab'uth-thiwal (the seven longest surahs of the Qur'an in terms of verses), namely Surah al-Baqarah, Ali 'Imran, al-Ma'idah, an-Nisa, al-A'raf, al-An'am, and at-Taubah or al-Anfal. These seven surahs are called as-sab'ul-matsani because in these seven surahs, the mention of stories, laws, monotheism, and others is repeated. However, this opinion contradicts the sahih hadiths above. Meanwhile, some of the surahs of as-sab'uth-thiwal were revealed in Medina, while the verse explaining as-sab'ul-matsani is Makkiyah.

It is called as-sab'ul-matsani (the seven repeatedly recited) because Surah al-Fatihah consists of seven verses that are repeatedly recited in each rakaat in prayer. A Muslim prays at least seventeen rakaats in a day and night. Therefore, they recite al-Fatihah at least seventeen times in a day and night. It is called the Grand Qur'an because the content of Surah al-Fatihah is the essence of the entire Qur'an, and it is also in accordance with the meaning of the hadith above.
text.88:
In the verse above, it is explained that Allah SWT has bestowed something of great value upon those who believe, namely Surah al-Fatihah. This bestowal is in the form of guidance to the right path and cannot be valued with any amount of wealth. Therefore, Allah SWT warns believers not to feel discouraged or saddened by the worldly pleasures that Allah has given to the disbelievers. It is not fitting for someone to turn their attention away from something noble and of high value to something of lesser value, especially if that worldly pleasure is obtained in a way that is not justified by Allah. All of that is temporary pleasure, and then they will be cast into the blazing fire of Hell. This verse is in line with the word of Allah SWT which forbids the Messenger from looking at the pleasures given to the disbelievers:

"And do not extend your eyes toward that by which We have given enjoyment to [certain] classes of them, [its being but] the splendor of worldly life by which We test them. And the provision of your Lord is better and more enduring." (Taha/20: 131)

Allah SWT forbade the Prophet Muhammad SAW from grieving over the disbelievers who did not heed his call. This prohibition from Allah is because the Prophet SAW greatly hoped that all people would believe and hoped that the disbelievers would not be afflicted with Allah's punishment in the Hereafter because of the vastness of His mercy. Allah's prohibition also reminds the Prophet SAW that his duty is only to convey the religion of Allah, not to force people to believe. Then Allah decided that the Prophet SAW should be gentle and tell the disbelievers that they would be afflicted with Allah's punishment if they continued in disbelief and error, as had been inflicted upon the nations before them.

This prohibition from Allah is because the Prophet SAW greatly hoped that all people would believe and hoped that the disbelievers would not be afflicted with Allah's punishment in the Hereafter due to the vastness of His mercy. Allah's prohibition also reminds the Prophet SAW that his duty is only to convey the religion of Allah, not to force people to believe. Then Allah decided that the Prophet SAW should be gentle and tell the disbelievers that they would be afflicted with Allah's torment if they continued in disbelief and error, as had been inflicted upon the nations before them.
text.90:
This verse explains that just as Allah has bestowed *as-sab'ul-matsani* upon the ummah of Prophet Muhammad, He has also bestowed something similar upon previous ummahs through the prophets who were sent to them. Just like the attitude and actions of previous ummahs towards the books revealed to them, so too was the attitude of the polytheists in Mecca who named the Qur'an with various names, such as poetry, magic, ancient fables, Muhammad's creation, and so on.

The *mufassirun* differ in opinion regarding the meaning of the word "al-muqtasimin" (those who divide).

The first opinion interprets *al-muqtasimin* as the disbelievers who swore that Allah would not resurrect the dead. This interpretation is in accordance with the word of Allah swt:

And they swear by Allah their strongest oaths, "Allah will not resurrect one who dies." No, but it is a true promise [binding] upon Him, but most of the people do not know. (an-Nahl/16: 38)

And the word of Allah swt:

Are these the ones whom you swore that Allah would never grant them mercy? (al-A'raf/7: 49)

The second opinion interprets *al-muqtasimin* as "those who divide" the Book of Allah, namely reducing, changing, and adding to the contents of the Book of Allah that was revealed to His messengers. The basis of their opinion is the word of Allah swt:

Then do you believe in a part of the Scripture and disbelieve in a part?... (al-Baqarah/2: 85)

And the word of Allah swt:

Among the Jews are those who distort words from their [proper] usages... (an-Nisa'/4: 46)

The third opinion interprets *al-muqtasimin* as "those who divide." The meaning is that they named the Qur'an according to the names they desired, so that people would not believe it as a book revealed by Allah. Their reason is the word of Allah swt:

Rather, they say, "[These are but] confused dreams, or rather, he has invented it, or rather, he is a poet." (al-Anbiya/21: 5)

The word of Allah swt:

And he said, "This is not but magic learned [from others]." (al-Muddatstsir/74: 24)

Each of the above opinions has strong arguments, but the most accurate and in accordance with these verses is the third opinion, especially when connected with the following verses, namely the word of Allah which means: "Those who have made the Qur'an into portions."

Al-Maragi, quoting the opinion of Ibn Abbas, said that the Jews and Christians also made the Qur'an into portions, some parts they believed, and some parts they denied.

Hasan al-Basri was of the opinion that the polytheists of Mecca divided the roads that people would pass through, then they stood on the roads that people would pass through and frightened those who would take the path that had been laid out by the Prophet saw.

text.94:
This verse commands the Prophet Muhammad (saw) to propagate the religion of Islam openly, no longer secretly, to challenge the polytheists, to not heed them and what they say, and to not fear those who hinder him in propagating the religion of Allah, because Allah protects him from their disturbances.

Some Quranic commentators interpret "Turn away from the polytheists" to mean do not pay attention to all kinds of actions of the polytheists who have denied, mocked, and opposed you. Do not let their actions prevent you from propagating the religion of Allah, because Allah preserves you from their disturbances.

text.96:
This verse provides assurance to the Prophet Muhammad that Allah SWT protects him from the actions of the polytheists of Mecca who mocked and harmed him, and protects the Qur'an from the efforts of those who want to defile it.

Ath-Thabari narrates from Sa'id bin Jubair that the polytheists of Mecca who mocked the Qur'an and the Prophet Muhammad were al-Walid bin Mugirah, al-'As bin Wa'il, Al-'Adi bin Qais, Aswad bin Abdu Yaguts, and Aswad bin Muththalib. They are all well-known in history, and the causes of their deaths were the result of their own actions.

According to a narration, it is explained that once the Prophet SAW was in front of the disbelievers of Mecca, they winked at each other without the Prophet Muhammad SAW knowing, and said to each other with the intention of mocking the Prophet, "Is this the person who claims to be a prophet?" At that time, Jibril (Gabriel) AS was with the Prophet, then Jibril pierced the backs of those who mocked him with his finger, causing marks, wounds, and festering ulcers with a foul odor. No one approached them because of the smell. Then this verse was revealed, affirming that the Prophet SAW was protected by Allah SWT from the disturbances of the disbelievers.

Allah knows that the Prophet SAW felt sad because of the mockery and actions of the disbelievers. To heal his sadness, Allah commanded the Prophet SAW to glorify Allah (tasbih), sanctify Allah from all things that associate partners with Him, pray (salat), bow (ruku'), prostrate (sujud), perform many acts of worship, do good, and restrain desires. This also applies to the Muslims until the end of their lives.
